title: Future Of Pakistani Politics In Presence Of PTI's Violent Ideology – OpEd
author: Muhammad Ali Raza
excerpt: Pakistan has been facing a greater level of political and economic instability since the dismissal of former Prime Minister Imran. The PTI chief was removed from office last 9 April, through the vo…
abstract: Pakistan has been facing a greater level of political and economic instability since the dismissal of former Prime Minister Imran. The PTI chief was removed from office last 9 April, through the vote of a no-confidence motion in Parliament. The vote of no-confidence motion was brought by the Pakistan Democratic Movement (PDM). PDM is a joint movement made by Pakistani political parties who were mainly in opposition then. However, later on, the PTI's coalition parties in government also defected to the PTI and joined the PDM which led the PTI leader to lose its vote confidence in Parliament.
authors: Daniel Erhovwo,Jane Koster,Joe Hebert,Muhammad Ali Raza,Wosene Getaneh

title: Sudanese parties delay signing of final political deal to April 6

abstract:
KHARTOUM, April 1 (Xinhua) -- Sudanese parties involved in the political process on Saturday agreed to postpone the signing of the final agreement to April 6.
 The decision was made during a meeting held at the Republican Palace here on Saturday that brought together Chairman of Sudan's Transitional Sovereign Council and Commander of the Sudanese army Abdel Fattah Al-Burhan, Deputy Chairman of the Sovereign Council and Commander of the Rapid Support Forces Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, leaders of the civilian forces, and representatives from the African Union, the United Nations and the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development.

title: China's top political advisor meets Singaporean PM
excerpt: (Xinhua) 13:35, April 01, 2023 Wang Huning, chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference National Committee, meets with Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in Beijing,…

(

13:35, April 01, 2023
 


Wang Huning, chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference National Committee, meets with Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in Beijing, capital of China, March 31, 2023. (Xinhua/Wang Ye)


BEIJING, March 31 (Xinhua) -- China's top political advisor Wang Huning met with Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in Beijing on Friday.


Wang, chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), said that under the strategic guidance of the two heads of state, both sides should maintain high-level exchanges, strengthen strategic communication, enhance political mutual trust, deepen high-quality cooperation, and join hands on the path to modernization.

title: Post-Election Reflection Workshop With Lesotho Political Parties [press release]
excerpt: In October 2022, Lesotho held a general election to elect Members of the National Assembly. Like in any other elections, political parties had to engage in and deal with some issues related to their…
abstract:
In October 2022, Lesotho held a general election to elect Members of the National Assembly. Like in any other elections, political parties had to engage in and deal with some issues related to their participation in these elections. These included campaigning, the nomination of candidates, mobilisation of voters, compliance with electoral laws and regulations, election monitoring and engaging with other electoral stakeholders, particularly the Independent Electoral Commissions of Lesotho.

Democracy Works Foundation in Lesotho within the framework of the Southern Africa Political Parties and Dialogue (SAPP&D) Programme engaged with registered political parties in pre-election capacity development and knowledge-sharing in order to contribute to strengthening the capacities of political parties for their meaningful participation in elections and the electoral processes.

title: Letter: A 'political' indictment ?
author: John Warnock
excerpt: If someone has been found by a Grand Jury to have probably committed a crime, the decision to indict that person cannot be 'political.' The decision NOT to indict could
abstract:
If someone has been found by a Grand Jury to have probably committed a crime, the decision to indict that person cannot be 'political.' The decision NOT to indict could be 'political.' There may be some, like the previous president, for whom everything, including science and the law, is political. If they say something is 'political,' it's a meaningless accusation since for them, nothing isn't.

John Warnock

Midtown

title: Rob Stein
author: Rob Stein
excerpt: Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.
abstract:
Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.

An award-winning science journalist with more than 30 years of experience, Stein mostly covers health and medicine. He tends to focus on stories that illustrate the intersection of science, health, politics, social trends, ethics, and federal science policy. He tracks genetics, stem cells, cancer research, women's health issues, and other science, medical, and health policy news.

Before NPR, Stein worked at The Washington Post for 16 years, first as the newspaper's science editor and then as a national health reporter.

, the first international standard-setting instrument on open science.


This Recommendation was adopted by 193 countries in November 2021 at the 41st session of the UNESCO General Conference. The Recommendation provides an internationally agreed definition and a set of shared values and guiding principles for open science.

title: Sioux Falls approves $5.1M purchase for various K-12 science curriculum
author: Morgan Matzen
excerpt: The Sioux Falls School District Board of Education approved a $5.1 million science curriculum purchase Monday night. Here's what that will go toward.
abstract:
The Sioux Falls School District Board of Education approved a $5.1 million science curriculum purchase Monday night that will help teach to the South Dakota Board of Education and Next Generation Science Standards in the 2023-2024 school year.
Total cost for the curriculum was $5,153,382, with $2,332,982 going to elementary school, $1,305,400 to middle school, $1,474,000 to high school, and $21,100 to special education for education materials supplied by Houghton Mifflin Harcourt and Attainment.
In elementary school, the resources, lab kits and teacher professional development to be purchased will come from Amplify.

title: Report Dissects Gaps In High School Computer Science
author: Sam Drysdale/SHNS
excerpt: Despite high demand for workers with tech skills, there are persistent gaps and inequities in computer science courses for Massachusetts high school students, according to a new report
abstract:
BOSTON (State House News Service) - Despite high demand for workers with tech skills, there are persistent gaps and inequities in computer science courses for Massachusetts high school students, according to a new report, which recommends that the state eventually mandate that students take a computer science class in order to graduate.

In the 2020-2021 school year, 84.7 percent of Massachusetts high school students attended a school that offered computer science, but only 5.8 percent of students were enrolled in a computer science course, according to the report by the Massachusetts Business Alliance for Education.

title: This course uses science fiction to understand politics
author: Nicole Pankiewicz
excerpt: Science fiction does more than entertain – it can also be used to better understand the political forces that shape the societies in which we live.
abstract:
Uncommon Courses is an occasional series from The Conversation U.S. highlighting unconventional approaches to teaching.

Title of course:

'Politics and Science Fiction'

What prompted the idea for the course?

While watching ' Andor ' – a science fiction TV series that is part of the 'Star Wars' galaxy of films, books and TV shows – I realized that what fascinates me most about science fiction is the political aspect, especially regarding power.

I decided to create an upper-level political science course that explores politics and government through the lens of science fiction, with a focus on literature.

title: Open Science NL Launches Regieorgaan for Research Coordination
author: Mirage News
excerpt: Fifteen knowledge institutions and the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science have signed the covenant for Open Science NL. Leiden University has
abstract:
Fifteen knowledge institutions and the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science have signed the covenant for Open Science NL. Leiden University has also joined the covenant, via the Universities of the Netherlands. This marks the start of the Dutch Research Council's and brings the transition to open science in the Netherlands a step further.

The covenant contains further agreements on the establishment of Open Science NL by the Dutch Research Council (NWO). The goal of Open Science NL is to further accelerate the transition to open science in the Netherlands.

title: It's time to rethink what citizen science really is, say researchers
author: Nick Hacking
excerpt: Citizen science is a popular method of gathering data for natural and social scientists, with the number of projects and publications produced growing year by year. A typical citizen science project…
abstract:
Citizen science is a popular method of gathering data for natural and social scientists, with the number of projects and publications produced 
growing year by year
. A typical citizen science project uses volunteers to gather data that would otherwise be unaffordable or inaccessible. 
 
 
But, based on the evidence we gathered during 
our study
 of a long-running planning dispute in south Wales, we think it's time to broaden our understanding of citizen science to include a much wider range of activities.

Title of course:

'Politics and Science Fiction'

What prompted the idea for the course?

While watching ' Andor ' – a science fiction TV series that is part of the 'Star Wars' galaxy of films, books and TV shows – I realized that what fascinates me most about science fiction is the political aspect, especially regarding power.

title: Rob Stein
author: Rob Stein
excerpt: Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.
abstract:
Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.
An award-winning science journalist with more than 30 years of experience, Stein mostly covers health and medicine. He tends to focus on stories that illustrate the intersection of science, health, politics, social trends, ethics, and federal science policy. He tracks genetics, stem cells, cancer research, women's health issues, and other science, medical, and health policy news.
Before NPR, Stein worked at 
The Washington Post
 for 16 years, first as the newspaper's science editor and then as a national health reporter.

title: Full STEAM Ahead: NC Science Festival spreads the joy of science across the state
author: WRAL
excerpt: This article was written for our sponsor, Morehead PlanetariumFor those who want to meet snakes and owls in a drive-thru tour, watch robots face off in a sumo wrestling sumo-bot competition, or talk…
abstract:
This article was written for our sponsor, 
Morehead Planetarium
For those who want to meet snakes and owls in a drive-thru tour, watch robots face off in a sumo wrestling sumo-bot competition, or talk about astronomy over a pint, the North Carolina Science Festival has everything you're looking for, and maybe some things you didn't even know you were looking for!
From making a bottle-rocket in Asheville and exploring the STEAM of racecars at the Charlotte Motor Speedway to learning how to help sustain our beautiful oceans, the statewide 
NC Science Festival
 truly offers opportunities to satisfy any curiosity and to spark a love of science in a huge variety of ways.

title: Sioux Falls approves $5.1M purchase for various K-12 science curriculum
author: Morgan Matzen
excerpt: The Sioux Falls School District Board of Education approved a $5.1 million science curriculum purchase Monday night. Here's what that will go toward.
abstract:
The Sioux Falls School District Board of Education approved a $5.1 million science curriculum purchase Monday night that will help teach to the South Dakota Board of Education and Next Generation Science Standards in the 2023-2024 school year.
Total cost for the curriculum was $5,153,382, with $2,332,982 going to elementary school, $1,305,400 to middle school, $1,474,000 to high school, and $21,100 to special education for education materials supplied by Houghton Mifflin Harcourt and Attainment.
In elementary school, the resources, lab kits and teacher professional development to be purchased will come from Amplify.

title: Epic experiments and rocket fun as schools celebrate British Science Week
author: Lewis Clarke
excerpt: British Science Week is a ten-day celebration of science, technology, engineering and maths
abstract:
British Science Week is a ten-day celebration of science, technology, engineering and maths
Schools across Devon have been conducting epic experiments and going out of this world for British Science Week. British Science Week is a ten-day celebration of science, technology, engineering and maths.
At Willowbank Primary School in Cullompton, Lizzie Playford, the year three and four teacher, said: 'British Science Week was out of this world. By thinking like scientists, pupils investigated how rocket design, with nose cone, body and fins, enables the rockets to blast out the atmosphere.

title: Amazon to fund access to computer science education for more than 2 million U.S. students
author: Written
excerpt: Amazon expands the reach of its childhood-to-career computer science education program that provides underserved and underrepresented communities access to STEM education.
abstract:
Amazon expands the reach of its childhood-to-career computer science education program that provides underserved and underrepresented communities access to STEM education.
 
 
Amazon is committed to providing access to computer science education for 2 million students, across almost 8,000 U.S. schools, by the end of the 2022–2023 academic year.
Through 
Amazon Future Engineer
, Amazon aims to inspire millions of students from underserved and historically underrepresented communities to pursue science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) careers.

title: Aztec school district renews education partnership
excerpt: Aztec Municipal School District renewed its partnership with Discovery Education for an additional two years, and will continue to use the company's Mystery Science service in its three elementary…
abstract:
Mystery Science program promotes science exploration
 
 
 
 
 
Aztec Municipal School District renewed its partnership with Discovery Education for an additional two years, and will continue to use the company's Mystery Science service in its three elementary schools.
 
The district originally selected Mystery Science to help teach students how to think like scientists and develop a lifelong love of learning.
 
Mystery Science provides educators simple to use, open-and-go, hands-on lessons that inspire students to love science.

title: Report dissects gaps in high school computer science
author: Sam Drysdale
excerpt: Despite high demand for workers with tech skills, there are persistent gaps and inequities in computer science courses for Massachusetts high school students, according to a new report, which…
abstract:
Despite high demand for workers with tech skills, there are persistent gaps and inequities in computer science courses for Massachusetts high school students, according to a new report, which recommends that the state eventually mandate that students take a computer science class in order to graduate.
In the 2020-2021 school year, 84.7% of Massachusetts high school students attended a school that offered computer science, but only 5.8% of students were enrolled in a computer science course, according to the report by the Massachusetts Business Alliance for Education.

title: Why are English majors studying computer science?
excerpt: Ten years ago, professors in computer science departments everywhere wondered how undergraduates from a broad range of fields could be attracted to computer science (CS). We were convinced that thi…
abstract:
Ten years ago, professors in computer science departments everywhere wondered how undergraduates from a broad range of fields could be attracted to computer science (CS). We were convinced that this material would be vital for their careers, but we were up against negative stereotypes of programmers, and the prediction that most software jobs were about to be outsourced to the third world.


The tide has turned! The graph below shows annual enrollments over the past decade for the introductory computer science courses at UC Berkeley, Stanford, and the University of Washington.

title: Best Online Master's in Data Science Programs in 2023
author: Fortune Education User
excerpt: Topping Fortune's ranking of online master's in data science programs are: 1. University of Southern California, 2. UC-Berkeley, 3. Bay Path University.
abstract:
Sort By
Los Angeles, CA
University of Southern California applicants don't need to submit GMAT or GRE scores to be considered for admission to its online data science master's program, however, international students must submit a TOEFL score. Accepted students, on average, have a 3.8 undergraduate GPA. Letters of recommendation are optional to apply. The acceptance rate to the program was 13% for the 2021-2022 year.

Al Seib—Los Angeles Times/Getty Images
Berkeley, CA
University of California—Berkeley applicants don't need to submit a GMAT or GRE score to be considered for admission into its master of information and data science program.

author: Pshravani
excerpt: Data analysis, preparation, and visualization are all part of the interdisciplinary discipline of data science, which uses structured and…
abstract:
Data analysis, preparation, and visualization are all part of the interdisciplinary discipline of data science, which uses structured and unstructured data to provide insightful findings. Professionals in this sector could choose to seek a specialization to develop their careers and become experts on the topic of their businesses.
If you are interested in a job in data science, deciding to specialize in one of the various subfields of data science will help you improve your abilities and qualifications and make you stand out from others in the field.

title: ORNL's Lee named Materials Research Society Fellow
author: Oak Ridge National Laboratory
excerpt: Ho Nyung Lee, a condensed matter physicist at the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory, has been elected a Fellow of the Materials Research So
abstract:
Newswise — Ho Nyung Lee, a condensed matter physicist at the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory, has been elected a Fellow of the Materials Research Society.
The society has more than 13,000 members from 90 countries. It selects fellows for their distinguished accomplishments and outstanding contributions in advancing materials research. It names fewer than 0.2% of current members as fellows.
The society lauded Lee 'for contributions to the advancement of precision synthesis and materials science of complex oxide thin films and heterostructures and for his leadership and service to the materials science community.

title: Teens get FREE admission to Science World for a sweet new event
author: Daniel Chai
excerpt: Food, glorious food is on the menu at Science World when teens will be treated to a fun and free night under the dome.
abstract:
Daniel Chai
Food, glorious food is on the menu at Science World this month when teens will be treated to a fun night under the dome.


Science World's Extravagant Evenings for Teens
, or SWEET, is inviting youths aged 13 to 18 to get culinary curious on Friday, April 14.


The free event takes place from 6 to 9 pm and will teach attendees all about the science of food.


 
 
Participants will discover where our food comes from and what goes into our relationship with food. Other questions that will be answered include why do we eat what we eat and what else can we do with food and its bi-products.

title: Shining Light on Science Education's Dark Age
author: Guest Blogger
excerpt: Possibly even worse than the promotion of 'consensus' was their endorsement of censorship of any scientific information that deviates from the consensus groupthink.
abstract:
by Gregory Wrightstone
 
The science teachers' bureaucracy is driving climate education into an unquestioning adherence to unscientific methodology. The cost will be measured in students without facility for the more than 400-year-old scientific method and lacking the critical thinking necessary for sustaining civilization and advancing humankind.
 
Many observers of education have been concerned for some time about the state of science education in America. Teaching, it seems, has drifted from open inquiry to an indoctrination of students into a political agenda.
authors: Coeur De Lion,Curious George,Dd More,Guest Blogger,Hoyt Clagwell,Krishna Gans,Lee Riffee,More Soylent Green,Peta,Tom Halla,William Howard

title: Overhaul of Arkansas' computer science requirement for high school students voted down
author: Neal Earley
excerpt: A bill to overhaul Arkansas' computer science requirement for high school students was defeated in committee Tuesday.
abstract:
A bill to overhaul Arkansas' computer science requirement for high school students was defeated in committee Tuesday.
Senate Bill 369 proposed giving more flexibility to students in career and technical education programs on how they can fulfill the state-mandated computer science requirement needed for graduation. Sen. Jim Dotson, R-Bentonville, the bill's sponsor, said the current computer science requirement is burdensome for students in a career and technical education program.
If approved, the bill would have allowed students to take a "computer science-related" course that is more applicable to their career path.

title: Iran pursues science diplomacy based on environmental protection
author: Best deals on hotels
excerpt: TEHRAN - The Islamic Republic of Iran pursues a policy of sustainable development in science and technology with a forward-looking view of humans and the environment, deputy science minister Peyman…
abstract:
TEHRAN - The Islamic Republic of Iran pursues a policy of sustainable development in science and technology with a forward-looking view of humans and the environment, deputy science minister Peyman Salehi has said.
'In this regard, we welcome the interaction and exchange of science and technology with all interested countries and consider science diplomacy as one of the key tools of international cooperation,' he added, IRNA reported.
He made the remarks addressing the 26th session of the Commission on Science and Technology for Development (CSTD) which was held from March 27 – 31 in Geneva, Switzerland.

Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.

An award-winning science journalist with more than 30 years of experience, Stein mostly covers health and medicine. He tends to focus on stories that illustrate the intersection of science, health, politics, social trends, ethics, and federal science policy. title: Three Science Educators Receive National Science Teaching Association's ‘Distinguished' Awards
author: Business Wire
excerpt: ARLINGTON, Va.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Mar 30, 2023--
abstract:
ARLINGTON, Va.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Mar 30, 2023--
The National Science Teaching Association (NSTA) announced the recipients of its 2023 'Distinguished' Awards: Distinguished Service to Science Education Award, Distinguished Teaching Award, and Distinguished Informal Science Education Award. NSTA annually recognizes extraordinary K–12 teachers, professors, principals, and science educators for their outstanding achievements in science education. The educators received their awards during a special evening celebration at NSTA's National Conference on Science Education in Atlanta, Georgia, on March 24.

title: UNESCO produces toolkit to advance open science
excerpt: Skip to main content What do we mean by open science?
abstract:
Skip to main content 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 



 
 
 
 
The UNESCO 
Open Science Toolkit
 has been designed to support implementation of the UNESCO 
Recommendation on Open Science
, the first international standard-setting instrument on open science.


This Recommendation was adopted by 193 countries in November 2021 at the 41st session of the UNESCO General Conference. The Recommendation provides an internationally agreed definition and a set of shared values and guiding principles for open science.

title: Report Dissects Gaps In High School Computer Science
author: Sam Drysdale/SHNS
excerpt: Despite high demand for workers with tech skills, there are persistent gaps and inequities in computer science courses for Massachusetts high school students, according to a new report
abstract:
BOSTON (State House News Service) - Despite high demand for workers with tech skills, there are persistent gaps and inequities in computer science courses for Massachusetts high school students, according to a new report, which recommends that the state eventually mandate that students take a computer science class in order to graduate.

In the 2020-2021 school year, 84.7 percent of Massachusetts high school students attended a school that offered computer science, but only 5.8 percent of students were enrolled in a computer science course, according to the report by the Massachusetts Business Alliance for Education.

author: Nicole Pankiewicz
excerpt: Science fiction does more than entertain – it can also be used to better understand the political forces that shape the societies in which we live.
abstract:
Uncommon Courses is an occasional series from The Conversation U.S. highlighting unconventional approaches to teaching.

Title of course:

'Politics and Science Fiction'

What prompted the idea for the course?

While watching ' Andor ' – a science fiction TV series that is part of the 'Star Wars' galaxy of films, books and TV shows – I realized that what fascinates me most about science fiction is the political aspect, especially regarding power.

I decided to create an upper-level political science course that explores politics and government through the lens of science fiction, with a focus on literature.

title: Open Science NL Launches Regieorgaan for Research Coordination
author: Mirage News
excerpt: Fifteen knowledge institutions and the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science have signed the covenant for Open Science NL. Leiden University has
abstract:
Fifteen knowledge institutions and the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science have signed the covenant for Open Science NL. Leiden University has also joined the covenant, via the Universities of the Netherlands. This marks the start of the Dutch Research Council's and brings the transition to open science in the Netherlands a step further.

The covenant contains further agreements on the establishment of Open Science NL by the Dutch Research Council (NWO). The goal of Open Science NL is to further accelerate the transition to open science in the Netherlands.

title: It's time to rethink what citizen science really is, say researchers
author: Nick Hacking
excerpt: Citizen science is a popular method of gathering data for natural and social scientists, with the number of projects and publications produced growing year by year. A typical citizen science project…
abstract:
Citizen science is a popular method of gathering data for natural and social scientists, with the number of projects and publications produced 
growing year by year
. A typical citizen science project uses volunteers to gather data that would otherwise be unaffordable or inaccessible. 
 
 
But, based on the evidence we gathered during 
our study
 of a long-running planning dispute in south Wales, we think it's time to broaden our understanding of citizen science to include a much wider range of activities.

title: Three New Hampshire Educators Finalists for Presidential Awards
author: NH Dept
excerpt: One of your neighbors posted in Schools. Click through to read what they have to say. (The views expressed in this post are the author's own.)
abstract:
CONCORD, NH (March 29, 2023) — Three Granite State educators have been chosen as the New Hampshire 2023 state finalists for the prestigious Presidential Awards for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching (PAEMST).

Joanne Goelzer, science teacher at Coe-Brown Northwood Academy in Northwood
Karen McCallion, science teacher at Epping Middle School in Epping
Sandra Swiechowicz, computer science teacher at Raymond High School in Raymond

'State finalists represent the most outstanding teachers New Hampshire has to offer, as they serve as both a role model and an inspiration to their students and fellow teachers,' said Frank Edelblut, education commissioner.

title: Rob Stein
author: Rob Stein
excerpt: Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.
abstract:
Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.
An award-winning science journalist with more than 30 years of experience, Stein mostly covers health and medicine. He tends to focus on stories that illustrate the intersection of science, health, politics, social trends, ethics, and federal science policy. He tracks genetics, stem cells, cancer research, women's health issues, and other science, medical, and health policy news.
Before NPR, Stein worked at 
The Washington Post
 for 16 years, first as the newspaper's science editor and then as a national health reporter.

title: Full STEAM Ahead: NC Science Festival spreads the joy of science across the state
author: WRAL
excerpt: This article was written for our sponsor, Morehead PlanetariumFor those who want to meet snakes and owls in a drive-thru tour, watch robots face off in a sumo wrestling sumo-bot competition, or talk…
abstract:
This article was written for our sponsor, 
Morehead Planetarium
For those who want to meet snakes and owls in a drive-thru tour, watch robots face off in a sumo wrestling sumo-bot competition, or talk about astronomy over a pint, the North Carolina Science Festival has everything you're looking for, and maybe some things you didn't even know you were looking for!
From making a bottle-rocket in Asheville and exploring the STEAM of racecars at the Charlotte Motor Speedway to learning how to help sustain our beautiful oceans, the statewide 
NC Science Festival
 truly offers opportunities to satisfy any curiosity and to spark a love of science in a huge variety of ways.

title: Sioux Falls approves $5.1M purchase for various K-12 science curriculum
author: Morgan Matzen
excerpt: The Sioux Falls School District Board of Education approved a $5.1 million science curriculum purchase Monday night. Here's what that will go toward.
abstract:
The Sioux Falls School District Board of Education approved a $5.1 million science curriculum purchase Monday night that will help teach to the South Dakota Board of Education and Next Generation Science Standards in the 2023-2024 school year.
Total cost for the curriculum was $5,153,382, with $2,332,982 going to elementary school, $1,305,400 to middle school, $1,474,000 to high school, and $21,100 to special education for education materials supplied by Houghton Mifflin Harcourt and Attainment.
In elementary school, the resources, lab kits and teacher professional development to be purchased will come from Amplify.

title: Epic experiments and rocket fun as schools celebrate British Science Week
author: Lewis Clarke
excerpt: British Science Week is a ten-day celebration of science, technology, engineering and maths
abstract:
British Science Week is a ten-day celebration of science, technology, engineering and maths
Schools across Devon have been conducting epic experiments and going out of this world for British Science Week. British Science Week is a ten-day celebration of science, technology, engineering and maths.
At Willowbank Primary School in Cullompton, Lizzie Playford, the year three and four teacher, said: 'British Science Week was out of this world. By thinking like scientists, pupils investigated how rocket design, with nose cone, body and fins, enables the rockets to blast out the atmosphere.

title: Amazon to fund access to computer science education for more than 2 million U.S. students
author: Written
excerpt: Amazon expands the reach of its childhood-to-career computer science education program that provides underserved and underrepresented communities access to STEM education.
abstract:
Amazon expands the reach of its childhood-to-career computer science education program that provides underserved and underrepresented communities access to STEM education.
 
 
Amazon is committed to providing access to computer science education for 2 million students, across almost 8,000 U.S. schools, by the end of the 2022–2023 academic year.
Through 
Amazon Future Engineer
, Amazon aims to inspire millions of students from underserved and historically underrepresented communities to pursue science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) careers.

title: Aztec school district renews education partnership
excerpt: Aztec Municipal School District renewed its partnership with Discovery Education for an additional two years, and will continue to use the company's Mystery Science service in its three elementary…
abstract:
Mystery Science program promotes science exploration
 
 
 
 
 
Aztec Municipal School District renewed its partnership with Discovery Education for an additional two years, and will continue to use the company's Mystery Science service in its three elementary schools.
 
The district originally selected Mystery Science to help teach students how to think like scientists and develop a lifelong love of learning.
 
Mystery Science provides educators simple to use, open-and-go, hands-on lessons that inspire students to love science.

title: Report dissects gaps in high school computer science
author: Sam Drysdale
excerpt: Despite high demand for workers with tech skills, there are persistent gaps and inequities in computer science courses for Massachusetts high school students, according to a new report, which…
abstract:
Despite high demand for workers with tech skills, there are persistent gaps and inequities in computer science courses for Massachusetts high school students, according to a new report, which recommends that the state eventually mandate that students take a computer science class in order to graduate.
In the 2020-2021 school year, 84.7% of Massachusetts high school students attended a school that offered computer science, but only 5.8% of students were enrolled in a computer science course, according to the report by the Massachusetts Business Alliance for Education.
authors: Dalia Ramirez Nerdwallet,Sam Drysdale,State House News

title: Why are English majors studying computer science?
excerpt: Ten years ago, professors in computer science departments everywhere wondered how undergraduates from a broad range of fields could be attracted to computer science (CS). We were convinced that thi…
abstract:
Ten years ago, professors in computer science departments everywhere wondered how undergraduates from a broad range of fields could be attracted to computer science (CS). We were convinced that this material would be vital for their careers, but we were up against negative stereotypes of programmers, and the prediction that most software jobs were about to be outsourced to the third world.


The tide has turned! The graph below shows annual enrollments over the past decade for the introductory computer science courses at UC Berkeley, Stanford, and the University of Washington.

title: Best Online Master's in Data Science Programs in 2023
author: Fortune Education User
excerpt: Topping Fortune's ranking of online master's in data science programs are: 1. University of Southern California, 2. UC-Berkeley, 3. Bay Path University.
abstract:
Sort By
Los Angeles, CA
University of Southern California applicants don't need to submit GMAT or GRE scores to be considered for admission to its online data science master's program, however, international students must submit a TOEFL score. Accepted students, on average, have a 3.8 undergraduate GPA. Letters of recommendation are optional to apply. The acceptance rate to the program was 13% for the 2021-2022 year.

Al Seib—Los Angeles Times/Getty Images
Berkeley, CA
University of California—Berkeley applicants don't need to submit a GMAT or GRE score to be considered for admission into its master of information and data science program.

abstract:
Data analysis, preparation, and visualization are all part of the interdisciplinary discipline of data science, which uses structured and unstructured data to provide insightful findings. Professionals in this sector could choose to seek a specialization to develop their careers and become experts on the topic of their businesses.
If you are interested in a job in data science, deciding to specialize in one of the various subfields of data science will help you improve your abilities and qualifications and make you stand out from others in the field.

title: Six Mississippi teachers named state-level finalists for PAEMST
author: Malaysia McCoy
excerpt: JACKSON, Miss. (WJTV) – Six 7th through 12th grade Mississippi teachers have been named 2022-23 state-level finalists for the Presidential Awards for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching…
abstract:
JACKSON, Miss. (WJTV) – Six 7th through 12th grade Mississippi teachers have been named 2022-23 state-level finalists for the Presidential Awards for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching (PAEMST).
The PAEMST program is the nation's highest honor for teachers of mathematics, science, technology, engineering and computer science education.
Two of these teachers will be selected for the PAEMST award. National honorees receive a $10,000 award from the National Science Foundation, recognition at a White House ceremony, and the opportunity to provide input on policies to improve science, technology, engineering, mathematics and computer science education.

title: ORNL's Lee named Materials Research Society Fellow
author: Oak Ridge National Laboratory
excerpt: Ho Nyung Lee, a condensed matter physicist at the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory, has been elected a Fellow of the Materials Research So
abstract:
Newswise — Ho Nyung Lee, a condensed matter physicist at the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory, has been elected a Fellow of the Materials Research Society.
The society has more than 13,000 members from 90 countries. It selects fellows for their distinguished accomplishments and outstanding contributions in advancing materials research. It names fewer than 0.2% of current members as fellows.
The society lauded Lee 'for contributions to the advancement of precision synthesis and materials science of complex oxide thin films and heterostructures and for his leadership and service to the materials science community.

title: Shining Light on Science Education's Dark Age
author: Guest Blogger
excerpt: Possibly even worse than the promotion of 'consensus' was their endorsement of censorship of any scientific information that deviates from the consensus groupthink.
abstract:
by Gregory Wrightstone
 
The science teachers' bureaucracy is driving climate education into an unquestioning adherence to unscientific methodology. The cost will be measured in students without facility for the more than 400-year-old scientific method and lacking the critical thinking necessary for sustaining civilization and advancing humankind.
 
Many observers of education have been concerned for some time about the state of science education in America. Teaching, it seems, has drifted from open inquiry to an indoctrination of students into a political agenda.
authors: Coeur De Lion,Curious George,Dd More,Guest Blogger,Hoyt Clagwell,Krishna Gans,Lee Riffee,More Soylent Green,Peta,Tom Halla,William Howard

title: Overhaul of Arkansas' computer science requirement for high school students voted down
author: Neal Earley
excerpt: A bill to overhaul Arkansas' computer science requirement for high school students was defeated in committee Tuesday.
abstract:
A bill to overhaul Arkansas' computer science requirement for high school students was defeated in committee Tuesday.
Senate Bill 369 proposed giving more flexibility to students in career and technical education programs on how they can fulfill the state-mandated computer science requirement needed for graduation. Sen. Jim Dotson, R-Bentonville, the bill's sponsor, said the current computer science requirement is burdensome for students in a career and technical education program.
If approved, the bill would have allowed students to take a "computer science-related" course that is more applicable to their career path.

title: Teens get FREE admission to Science World for a sweet new event
author: Daniel Chai
excerpt: Food, glorious food is on the menu at Science World when teens will be treated to a fun and free night under the dome.
abstract:
Daniel Chai
Food, glorious food is on the menu at Science World this month when teens will be treated to a fun night under the dome.


Science World's Extravagant Evenings for Teens
, or SWEET, is inviting youths aged 13 to 18 to get culinary curious on Friday, April 14.


The free event takes place from 6 to 9 pm and will teach attendees all about the science of food.


 
 
Participants will discover where our food comes from and what goes into our relationship with food. Other questions that will be answered include why do we eat what we eat and what else can we do with food and its bi-products.

title: Three Science Educators Receive National Science Teaching Association's ‘Distinguished' Awards
author: Business Wire
excerpt: ARLINGTON, Va.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Mar 30, 2023--
abstract:
ARLINGTON, Va.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Mar 30, 2023--
The National Science Teaching Association (NSTA) announced the recipients of its 2023 'Distinguished' Awards: Distinguished Service to Science Education Award, Distinguished Teaching Award, and Distinguished Informal Science Education Award. NSTA annually recognizes extraordinary K–12 teachers, professors, principals, and science educators for their outstanding achievements in science education. The educators received their awards during a special evening celebration at NSTA's National Conference on Science Education in Atlanta, Georgia, on March 24.

      HK SciFest 2023, organised by the Science Promotion Unit of the Hong Kong Science Museum, will be held from today (March 31) to April 16 with the theme of "Science Around You". title: UNESCO produces toolkit to advance open science
excerpt: Skip to main content What do we mean by open science?
abstract:
Skip to main content 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 



 
 
 
 
The UNESCO 
Open Science Toolkit
 has been designed to support implementation of the UNESCO 
Recommendation on Open Science
, the first international standard-setting instrument on open science.


This Recommendation was adopted by 193 countries in November 2021 at the 41st session of the UNESCO General Conference. The Recommendation provides an internationally agreed definition and a set of shared values and guiding principles for open science.

title: This course uses science fiction to understand politics
author: Nicole Pankiewicz
excerpt: Science fiction does more than entertain – it can also be used to better understand the political forces that shape the societies in which we live.
abstract:
Uncommon Courses is an occasional series from The Conversation U.S. highlighting unconventional approaches to teaching.

Title of course:

'Politics and Science Fiction'

What prompted the idea for the course?

While watching ' Andor ' – a science fiction TV series that is part of the 'Star Wars' galaxy of films, books and TV shows – I realized that what fascinates me most about science fiction is the political aspect, especially regarding power.

I decided to create an upper-level political science course that explores politics and government through the lens of science fiction, with a focus on literature.

title: Open Science NL Launches Regieorgaan for Research Coordination
author: Mirage News
excerpt: Fifteen knowledge institutions and the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science have signed the covenant for Open Science NL. Leiden University has
abstract:
Fifteen knowledge institutions and the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science have signed the covenant for Open Science NL. Leiden University has also joined the covenant, via the Universities of the Netherlands. This marks the start of the Dutch Research Council's and brings the transition to open science in the Netherlands a step further.

The covenant contains further agreements on the establishment of Open Science NL by the Dutch Research Council (NWO). The goal of Open Science NL is to further accelerate the transition to open science in the Netherlands.

title: Full STEAM Ahead: NC Science Festival spreads the joy of science across the state
author: WRAL
excerpt: This article was written for our sponsor, Morehead PlanetariumFor those who want to meet snakes and owls in a drive-thru tour, watch robots face off in a sumo wrestling sumo-bot competition, or talk…
abstract:
This article was written for our sponsor, 
Morehead Planetarium
For those who want to meet snakes and owls in a drive-thru tour, watch robots face off in a sumo wrestling sumo-bot competition, or talk about astronomy over a pint, the North Carolina Science Festival has everything you're looking for, and maybe some things you didn't even know you were looking for!
From making a bottle-rocket in Asheville and exploring the STEAM of racecars at the Charlotte Motor Speedway to learning how to help sustain our beautiful oceans, the statewide 
NC Science Festival
 truly offers opportunities to satisfy any curiosity and to spark a love of science in a huge variety of ways.

title: Three New Hampshire Educators Finalists for Presidential Awards
author: NH Dept
excerpt: One of your neighbors posted in Schools. Click through to read what they have to say. (The views expressed in this post are the author's own.)
abstract:
CONCORD, NH (March 29, 2023) — Three Granite State educators have been chosen as the New Hampshire 2023 state finalists for the prestigious Presidential Awards for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching (PAEMST).

Joanne Goelzer, science teacher at Coe-Brown Northwood Academy in Northwood
Karen McCallion, science teacher at Epping Middle School in Epping
Sandra Swiechowicz, computer science teacher at Raymond High School in Raymond

'State finalists represent the most outstanding teachers New Hampshire has to offer, as they serve as both a role model and an inspiration to their students and fellow teachers,' said Frank Edelblut, education commissioner.

title: Rob Stein
author: Rob Stein
excerpt: Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.
abstract:
Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.
An award-winning science journalist with more than 30 years of experience, Stein mostly covers health and medicine. He tends to focus on stories that illustrate the intersection of science, health, politics, social trends, ethics, and federal science policy. He tracks genetics, stem cells, cancer research, women's health issues, and other science, medical, and health policy news.
Before NPR, Stein worked at 
The Washington Post
 for 16 years, first as the newspaper's science editor and then as a national health reporter.

title: Amazon to fund access to computer science education for more than 2 million U.S. students
author: Written
excerpt: Amazon expands the reach of its childhood-to-career computer science education program that provides underserved and underrepresented communities access to STEM education.
abstract:
Amazon expands the reach of its childhood-to-career computer science education program that provides underserved and underrepresented communities access to STEM education.
 
 
Amazon is committed to providing access to computer science education for 2 million students, across almost 8,000 U.S. schools, by the end of the 2022–2023 academic year.
Through 
Amazon Future Engineer
, Amazon aims to inspire millions of students from underserved and historically underrepresented communities to pursue science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) careers.

title: Aztec school district renews education partnership
excerpt: Aztec Municipal School District renewed its partnership with Discovery Education for an additional two years, and will continue to use the company's Mystery Science service in its three elementary…
abstract:
Mystery Science program promotes science exploration
 
 
 
 
 
Aztec Municipal School District renewed its partnership with Discovery Education for an additional two years, and will continue to use the company's Mystery Science service in its three elementary schools.
 
The district originally selected Mystery Science to help teach students how to think like scientists and develop a lifelong love of learning.
 
Mystery Science provides educators simple to use, open-and-go, hands-on lessons that inspire students to love science.

title: Report dissects gaps in high school computer science
author: Sam Drysdale
excerpt: Despite high demand for workers with tech skills, there are persistent gaps and inequities in computer science courses for Massachusetts high school students, according to a new report, which…
abstract:
Despite high demand for workers with tech skills, there are persistent gaps and inequities in computer science courses for Massachusetts high school students, according to a new report, which recommends that the state eventually mandate that students take a computer science class in order to graduate.
In the 2020-2021 school year, 84.7% of Massachusetts high school students attended a school that offered computer science, but only 5.8% of students were enrolled in a computer science course, according to the report by the Massachusetts Business Alliance for Education.

title: Six Mississippi teachers named state-level finalists for PAEMST
author: Malaysia McCoy
excerpt: JACKSON, Miss. (WJTV) – Six 7th through 12th grade Mississippi teachers have been named 2022-23 state-level finalists for the Presidential Awards for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching…
abstract:
JACKSON, Miss. (WJTV) – Six 7th through 12th grade Mississippi teachers have been named 2022-23 state-level finalists for the Presidential Awards for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching (PAEMST).
The PAEMST program is the nation's highest honor for teachers of mathematics, science, technology, engineering and computer science education.
Two of these teachers will be selected for the PAEMST award. National honorees receive a $10,000 award from the National Science Foundation, recognition at a White House ceremony, and the opportunity to provide input on policies to improve science, technology, engineering, mathematics and computer science education.

title: Why are English majors studying computer science?
excerpt: Ten years ago, professors in computer science departments everywhere wondered how undergraduates from a broad range of fields could be attracted to computer science (CS). We were convinced that thi…
abstract:
Ten years ago, professors in computer science departments everywhere wondered how undergraduates from a broad range of fields could be attracted to computer science (CS). We were convinced that this material would be vital for their careers, but we were up against negative stereotypes of programmers, and the prediction that most software jobs were about to be outsourced to the third world.


The tide has turned! The graph below shows annual enrollments over the past decade for the introductory computer science courses at UC Berkeley, Stanford, and the University of Washington.

title: Data Science Specialization and Types
author: Pshravani
excerpt: Data analysis, preparation, and visualization are all part of the interdisciplinary discipline of data science, which uses structured and…
abstract:
Data analysis, preparation, and visualization are all part of the interdisciplinary discipline of data science, which uses structured and unstructured data to provide insightful findings. Professionals in this sector could choose to seek a specialization to develop their careers and become experts on the topic of their businesses.
If you are interested in a job in data science, deciding to specialize in one of the various subfields of data science will help you improve your abilities and qualifications and make you stand out from others in the field.

title: Where the future meets the past: 'Steampunk' party planned April 14 at OKC science museum
author: Jessie Christopher Smith
excerpt: The Science Museum Oklahoma is hosting a science fiction-themed event for one night in mid-April.
abstract:
Oklahoma City's popular science museum plans to host a science fiction-themed event for one night only in mid-April.
Located at 2020 Remington Place, Science Museum Oklahoma will hold its SMO21: Steampunk event Friday, April 14, from 7 p.m. to 10 p.m.
'Whether you take inspiration from the Victorian age or the American Wild West, Steampunk will be on display the entire night,' the science museum announced on its website. 'We're taking a journey like no other, where you'll be whisked away to the 1800s and a fantastical land of haberdashery, tufting, tea dueling, metal working and so much more!''Steampunk' is a subgenre of 'retro-futuristic' science fiction, exemplified by H.

title: ORNL's Lee named Materials Research Society Fellow
author: Oak Ridge National Laboratory
excerpt: Ho Nyung Lee, a condensed matter physicist at the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory, has been elected a Fellow of the Materials Research So
abstract:
Newswise — Ho Nyung Lee, a condensed matter physicist at the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory, has been elected a Fellow of the Materials Research Society.
The society has more than 13,000 members from 90 countries. It selects fellows for their distinguished accomplishments and outstanding contributions in advancing materials research. It names fewer than 0.2% of current members as fellows.
The society lauded Lee 'for contributions to the advancement of precision synthesis and materials science of complex oxide thin films and heterostructures and for his leadership and service to the materials science community.

title: Teens get FREE admission to Science World for a sweet new event
author: Daniel Chai
excerpt: Food, glorious food is on the menu at Science World when teens will be treated to a fun and free night under the dome.
abstract:
Daniel Chai
Food, glorious food is on the menu at Science World this month when teens will be treated to a fun night under the dome.


Science World's Extravagant Evenings for Teens
, or SWEET, is inviting youths aged 13 to 18 to get culinary curious on Friday, April 14.


The free event takes place from 6 to 9 pm and will teach attendees all about the science of food.


 
 
Participants will discover where our food comes from and what goes into our relationship with food. Other questions that will be answered include why do we eat what we eat and what else can we do with food and its bi-products.

title: Iran pursues science diplomacy based on environmental protection
author: Best deals on hotels
excerpt: TEHRAN - The Islamic Republic of Iran pursues a policy of sustainable development in science and technology with a forward-looking view of humans and the environment, deputy science minister Peyman…
abstract:
TEHRAN - The Islamic Republic of Iran pursues a policy of sustainable development in science and technology with a forward-looking view of humans and the environment, deputy science minister Peyman Salehi has said.
'In this regard, we welcome the interaction and exchange of science and technology with all interested countries and consider science diplomacy as one of the key tools of international cooperation,' he added, IRNA reported.
He made the remarks addressing the 26th session of the Commission on Science and Technology for Development (CSTD) which was held from March 27 – 31 in Geneva, Switzerland.

These awards go to individuals who were working at the front lines of science communication or journalism, with nine awards for research scientists, nine awards for science journalists, and, new to this year, six awards for science communicators.
abstract:
, April 4, 2023 /PRNewswire/ -- Submissions are now being accepted for the 2023 Eric and Wendy Schmidt Awards for Excellence in Science Communications, given by the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine in partnership with Schmidt Futures.

This application cycle marks the second year of the Eric and Wendy Schmidt Awards for Excellence in Science Communications which honor top science communicators, journalists, and research scientists who have developed creative, original work to communicate issues and advances in science, engineering, and/or medicine for the general public.

title: Three Science Educators Receive National Science Teaching Association's ‘Distinguished' Awards
author: Business Wire
excerpt: ARLINGTON, Va.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Mar 30, 2023--
abstract:
ARLINGTON, Va.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Mar 30, 2023--
The National Science Teaching Association (NSTA) announced the recipients of its 2023 'Distinguished' Awards: Distinguished Service to Science Education Award, Distinguished Teaching Award, and Distinguished Informal Science Education Award. NSTA annually recognizes extraordinary K–12 teachers, professors, principals, and science educators for their outstanding achievements in science education. The educators received their awards during a special evening celebration at NSTA's National Conference on Science Education in Atlanta, Georgia, on March 24.

HK SciFest 2023 opens with over 140 fun science activities for the public (with photos)
 
 
***************************************************************************************
 
 
      HK SciFest 2023, organised by the Science Promotion Unit of the Hong Kong Science Museum, will be held from today (March 31) to April 16 with the theme of "Science Around You". The science museum is collaborating with more than 70 science organisations, education institutions, schools, tertiary institutions, museums, 14 government departments and related organisations to offer over 140 science-related activities for the public to discover the fun in science.

title: UNESCO produces toolkit to advance open science
excerpt: Skip to main content What do we mean by open science?
abstract:
Skip to main content 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 



 
 
 
 
The UNESCO 
Open Science Toolkit
 has been designed to support implementation of the UNESCO 
Recommendation on Open Science
, the first international standard-setting instrument on open science.


This Recommendation was adopted by 193 countries in November 2021 at the 41st session of the UNESCO General Conference. The Recommendation provides an internationally agreed definition and a set of shared values and guiding principles for open science.

title: Rob Stein
author: Rob Stein
excerpt: Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.
abstract:
Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.

An award-winning science journalist with more than 30 years of experience, Stein mostly covers health and medicine. He tends to focus on stories that illustrate the intersection of science, health, politics, social trends, ethics, and federal science policy. He tracks genetics, stem cells, cancer research, women's health issues, and other science, medical, and health policy news.

Before NPR, Stein worked at The Washington Post for 16 years, first as the newspaper's science editor and then as a national health reporter.

Total cost for the curriculum was $5,153,382, with $2,332,982 going to elementary school, $1,305,400 to middle school, $1,474,000 to high school, and $21,100 to special education for education materials supplied by Houghton Mifflin Harcourt and Attainment.
In elementary school, the resources, lab kits and teacher professional development to be purchased will come from Amplify.

title: Report Dissects Gaps In High School Computer Science
author: Sam Drysdale/SHNS
excerpt: Despite high demand for workers with tech skills, there are persistent gaps and inequities in computer science courses for Massachusetts high school students, according to a new report
abstract:
BOSTON (State House News Service) - Despite high demand for workers with tech skills, there are persistent gaps and inequities in computer science courses for Massachusetts high school students, according to a new report, which recommends that the state eventually mandate that students take a computer science class in order to graduate.

In the 2020-2021 school year, 84.7 percent of Massachusetts high school students attended a school that offered computer science, but only 5.8 percent of students were enrolled in a computer science course, according to the report by the Massachusetts Business Alliance for Education.

title: This course uses science fiction to understand politics
author: Nicole Pankiewicz
excerpt: Science fiction does more than entertain – it can also be used to better understand the political forces that shape the societies in which we live.
abstract:
Uncommon Courses is an occasional series from The Conversation U.S. highlighting unconventional approaches to teaching.

Title of course:

'Politics and Science Fiction'

What prompted the idea for the course?

While watching ' Andor ' – a science fiction TV series that is part of the 'Star Wars' galaxy of films, books and TV shows – I realized that what fascinates me most about science fiction is the political aspect, especially regarding power.

I decided to create an upper-level political science course that explores politics and government through the lens of science fiction, with a focus on literature.

title: Open Science NL Launches Regieorgaan for Research Coordination
author: Mirage News
excerpt: Fifteen knowledge institutions and the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science have signed the covenant for Open Science NL. Leiden University has
abstract:
Fifteen knowledge institutions and the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science have signed the covenant for Open Science NL. Leiden University has also joined the covenant, via the Universities of the Netherlands. This marks the start of the Dutch Research Council's and brings the transition to open science in the Netherlands a step further.

The covenant contains further agreements on the establishment of Open Science NL by the Dutch Research Council (NWO). The goal of Open Science NL is to further accelerate the transition to open science in the Netherlands.

title: It's time to rethink what citizen science really is, say researchers
author: Nick Hacking
excerpt: Citizen science is a popular method of gathering data for natural and social scientists, with the number of projects and publications produced growing year by year. A typical citizen science project…
abstract:
Citizen science is a popular method of gathering data for natural and social scientists, with the number of projects and publications produced 
growing year by year
. A typical citizen science project uses volunteers to gather data that would otherwise be unaffordable or inaccessible. 
 
 
But, based on the evidence we gathered during 
our study
 of a long-running planning dispute in south Wales, we think it's time to broaden our understanding of citizen science to include a much wider range of activities.

title: Full STEAM Ahead: NC Science Festival spreads the joy of science across the state
author: WRAL
excerpt: This article was written for our sponsor, Morehead PlanetariumFor those who want to meet snakes and owls in a drive-thru tour, watch robots face off in a sumo wrestling sumo-bot competition, or talk…
abstract:
This article was written for our sponsor, 
Morehead Planetarium
For those who want to meet snakes and owls in a drive-thru tour, watch robots face off in a sumo wrestling sumo-bot competition, or talk about astronomy over a pint, the North Carolina Science Festival has everything you're looking for, and maybe some things you didn't even know you were looking for!
From making a bottle-rocket in Asheville and exploring the STEAM of racecars at the Charlotte Motor Speedway to learning how to help sustain our beautiful oceans, the statewide 
NC Science Festival
 truly offers opportunities to satisfy any curiosity and to spark a love of science in a huge variety of ways.

title: Amazon to fund access to computer science education for more than 2 million U.S. students
author: Written
excerpt: Amazon expands the reach of its childhood-to-career computer science education program that provides underserved and underrepresented communities access to STEM education.
abstract:
Amazon expands the reach of its childhood-to-career computer science education program that provides underserved and underrepresented communities access to STEM education.
 
 
Amazon is committed to providing access to computer science education for 2 million students, across almost 8,000 U.S. schools, by the end of the 2022–2023 academic year.
Through 
Amazon Future Engineer
, Amazon aims to inspire millions of students from underserved and historically underrepresented communities to pursue science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) careers.

title: Aztec school district renews education partnership
excerpt: Aztec Municipal School District renewed its partnership with Discovery Education for an additional two years, and will continue to use the company's Mystery Science service in its three elementary…
abstract:
Mystery Science program promotes science exploration
 
 
 
 
 
Aztec Municipal School District renewed its partnership with Discovery Education for an additional two years, and will continue to use the company's Mystery Science service in its three elementary schools.
 
The district originally selected Mystery Science to help teach students how to think like scientists and develop a lifelong love of learning.
 
Mystery Science provides educators simple to use, open-and-go, hands-on lessons that inspire students to love science.

title: Why are English majors studying computer science?
excerpt: Ten years ago, professors in computer science departments everywhere wondered how undergraduates from a broad range of fields could be attracted to computer science (CS). We were convinced that thi…
abstract:
Ten years ago, professors in computer science departments everywhere wondered how undergraduates from a broad range of fields could be attracted to computer science (CS). We were convinced that this material would be vital for their careers, but we were up against negative stereotypes of programmers, and the prediction that most software jobs were about to be outsourced to the third world.


The tide has turned! The graph below shows annual enrollments over the past decade for the introductory computer science courses at UC Berkeley, Stanford, and the University of Washington.

title: Best Online Master's in Data Science Programs in 2023
author: Fortune Education User
excerpt: Topping Fortune's ranking of online master's in data science programs are: 1. University of Southern California, 2. UC-Berkeley, 3. Bay Path University.
abstract:
Sort By
Los Angeles, CA
University of Southern California applicants don't need to submit GMAT or GRE scores to be considered for admission to its online data science master's program, however, international students must submit a TOEFL score. Accepted students, on average, have a 3.8 undergraduate GPA. Letters of recommendation are optional to apply. The acceptance rate to the program was 13% for the 2021-2022 year.

Al Seib—Los Angeles Times/Getty Images
Berkeley, CA
University of California—Berkeley applicants don't need to submit a GMAT or GRE score to be considered for admission into its master of information and data science program.

abstract:
Data analysis, preparation, and visualization are all part of the interdisciplinary discipline of data science, which uses structured and unstructured data to provide insightful findings. Professionals in this sector could choose to seek a specialization to develop their careers and become experts on the topic of their businesses.
If you are interested in a job in data science, deciding to specialize in one of the various subfields of data science will help you improve your abilities and qualifications and make you stand out from others in the field.

title: Teens get FREE admission to Science World for a sweet new event
author: Daniel Chai
excerpt: Food, glorious food is on the menu at Science World when teens will be treated to a fun and free night under the dome.
abstract:
Daniel Chai
Food, glorious food is on the menu at Science World this month when teens will be treated to a fun night under the dome.


Science World's Extravagant Evenings for Teens
, or SWEET, is inviting youths aged 13 to 18 to get culinary curious on Friday, April 14.


The free event takes place from 6 to 9 pm and will teach attendees all about the science of food.


 
 
Participants will discover where our food comes from and what goes into our relationship with food. Other questions that will be answered include why do we eat what we eat and what else can we do with food and its bi-products.

abstract:
Newswise — Ho Nyung Lee, a condensed matter physicist at the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory, has been elected a Fellow of the Materials Research Society.
The society has more than 13,000 members from 90 countries. It selects fellows for their distinguished accomplishments and outstanding contributions in advancing materials research. It names fewer than 0.2% of current members as fellows.
The society lauded Lee 'for contributions to the advancement of precision synthesis and materials science of complex oxide thin films and heterostructures and for his leadership and service to the materials science community.

title: Shining Light on Science Education's Dark Age
author: Guest Blogger
excerpt: Possibly even worse than the promotion of 'consensus' was their endorsement of censorship of any scientific information that deviates from the consensus groupthink.
abstract:
by Gregory Wrightstone
 
The science teachers' bureaucracy is driving climate education into an unquestioning adherence to unscientific methodology. The cost will be measured in students without facility for the more than 400-year-old scientific method and lacking the critical thinking necessary for sustaining civilization and advancing humankind.
 
Many observers of education have been concerned for some time about the state of science education in America. Teaching, it seems, has drifted from open inquiry to an indoctrination of students into a political agenda.

title: Overhaul of Arkansas' computer science requirement for high school students voted down
author: Neal Earley
excerpt: A bill to overhaul Arkansas' computer science requirement for high school students was defeated in committee Tuesday.
abstract:
A bill to overhaul Arkansas' computer science requirement for high school students was defeated in committee Tuesday.
Senate Bill 369 proposed giving more flexibility to students in career and technical education programs on how they can fulfill the state-mandated computer science requirement needed for graduation. Sen. Jim Dotson, R-Bentonville, the bill's sponsor, said the current computer science requirement is burdensome for students in a career and technical education program.
If approved, the bill would have allowed students to take a "computer science-related" course that is more applicable to their career path.

title: Iran pursues science diplomacy based on environmental protection
author: Best deals on hotels
excerpt: TEHRAN - The Islamic Republic of Iran pursues a policy of sustainable development in science and technology with a forward-looking view of humans and the environment, deputy science minister Peyman…
abstract:
TEHRAN - The Islamic Republic of Iran pursues a policy of sustainable development in science and technology with a forward-looking view of humans and the environment, deputy science minister Peyman Salehi has said.
'In this regard, we welcome the interaction and exchange of science and technology with all interested countries and consider science diplomacy as one of the key tools of international cooperation,' he added, IRNA reported.
He made the remarks addressing the 26th session of the Commission on Science and Technology for Development (CSTD) which was held from March 27 – 31 in Geneva, Switzerland.

title: Rob Stein
author: Rob Stein
excerpt: Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.
abstract:
Rob Stein is a correspondent and senior editor on NPR's science desk.

An award-winning science journalist with more than 30 years of experience, Stein mostly covers health and medicine. He tends to focus on stories that illustrate the intersection of science, health, politics, social trends, ethics, and federal science policy. He tracks genetics, stem cells, cancer research, women's health issues, and other science, medical, and health policy news.

Before NPR, Stein worked at The Washington Post for 16 years, first as the newspaper's science editor and then as a national health reporter.

title: How to Do Market Research: A Guide and Template
author: Debbie Farese
excerpt: Discover the different types of market research, how to conduct your own market research, and use a free template to help you along the way.
abstract:
Today's consumers have a lot of power. They can research your product or service and make purchase decisions entirely on their own.

Moreover, rather than talking to one of your sales reps, they're more likely to ask for referrals from members of their networks or read online reviews.

With this in mind, have you adapted your marketing strategy to complement the way today's consumers research, shop, and buy?

To do just that, you must have a deep understanding of who your buyers are, your specific market, and what influences the purchase decisions and behavior of your target audience members.

BACKGROUND ON IMPACT AND REACH


IMPACT Initiatives is a humanitarian think tank, based in Geneva, . The organisation manages several initiatives, including the REACH Initiative, which was created in 2010 to facilitate the development of information tools and products that enhance the capacity of aid actors to make evidence-based decisions in emergency, recovery and development contexts. The IMPACT team comprises of specialists in research design; data collection, management and analysis; GIS and remote-sensing.

title: UK Investment Research Review Call for Evidence Published
author: Sandy Collins
excerpt: The U.K. Investment Research Review call for evidence was published on April 3, 2023. Relevant background to these issues is set out in our recent…
abstract:
USA





April 5 2023





The U.K. 
Investment Research Review call for evidence
 was published on April 3, 2023. Relevant background to these issues is set out in our recent client note, '
MiFID II: An Update on the Rules for Unbundling of Research
,' in which we discussed the MiFID II requirements, the actions of the U.S. SEC, potential changes to the U.K. and EU MiFID II rules and the implications for broker-dealers that receive 'hard dollars' for research. In summary, the research that investment managers typically receive from brokers is, under MiFID II, generally classified as a prohibited 'inducement,' unless the investment manager pays for the research either: (a) directly from its own resources; (b) from a 'Research Payment Account' (RPA) funded, with the client's prior approval, with an advisory client's money; or (c) a combination of the two methods.

title: State Secretary Martina Hirayama receives delegation from Greenland
author: The Federal Council
excerpt: Bern, 03.04.2023 - On 3 April, Martina Hirayama, State Secretary for Education, Research and Innovation, welcomed Aqqaluaq B. Egede, Greenland's Minister for Natural Resources and Justice, to…
abstract:
Bern, 03.04.2023 - On 3 April, Martina Hirayama, State Secretary for Education, Research and Innovation, welcomed Aqqaluaq B. Egede, Greenland's Minister for Natural Resources and Justice, to Switzerland. Switzerland and Greenland have cooperated closely in research for many years, particularly in the field of polar research. 
 
 
The talks between State Secretary Martina Hirayama and Minister Aqqaluaq B. Egede focused on strengthening research cooperation between Switzerland and Greenland. The meeting took place on the fringes of a trip to Switzerland by a Greenlandic delegation to discuss risk management in the Swiss Alps.

abstract:
The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) produces a wealth of data and other resources that support research across health economics, epidemiology, health services research, and related fields. On April 25, the Brookings 
Center on Regulation and Markets
 will hold a workshop for young scholars to explore these topics.


The workshop will introduce participants to a number of AHRQ's core datasets, with a focus on how they may be used to support research in health economics by graduate students and early-stage scholars.

abstract:
As the leading research institute in New Mexico, UNM strives to recognize its student and faculty research initiatives. The University Libraries is a proud supporter of this and is happy to announce the five recipients of the 2023 Jim and Mary Lois Friday Hulsman Undergraduate Library Research Awards. 
 
This prestigious award aims to shine a light on both emerging and advanced research in undergraduates. The award accepts original research projects completed by individuals or groups in all formats including, research papers, design portfolios, compositions, posters and digital projects.

title: Medicine and Healthcare Journals at PLOS
excerpt: Discover medicine and healthcare journals at PLOS, your open access home for accelerating global research discovery.
abstract:
Work of global societal importance deserves a global platform. We make medical and healthcare research accessible to read without fees, limits or delays.  From the greatest advances in well-known challenges to discoveries in emerging topics, there's a home for a broad range of medical and healthcare research at PLOS.
 
Improving access to medicine and healthcare research
 
In 2022, we shared research from over 6,916 authors in 99 countries, and received over 47,100 mentions worldwide*.
 
Plan S & funder compliance
 
As more and more publishers begin to offer Open Access options, finding out whether or not your article will meet funder requirements can leave some researchers feeling confused.

Grants for Catalyzing Research Clusters
